comment.author: 69703983@N02
comment._content: Seeing this picture gallery made me feel very humble and understand what Remembrance Day is all about. Many thanks to all the brave souls, many of who gave their lives to make the world a better place. Deservedly may they R.I.P.

comment.author: 32300107@N06
comment._content: Thank you. If you have a spare minute, please light a light to help us remember those who died in the First World War, at www.1914.org/wall/

comment.author: 45500782@N06
comment._content:
What about the fighters of WW2

My late dad was in the RN during WW2

He was on 3 mine ships, (looking for sea mines, planted by the Germans,) HMS Flint,  HMS Europa & HMS Spartiate.

All 3 ships found at least 1 mine each, as the all got blown up.

My dad survived them all.

He died in 2003 he was 82

I have proof of all this from the RN archives.

Why is he not in the gallery. ?

comment.author: 69687580@N05
comment._content:
I want to say that having scrolled through all these photos and comments and having family that have served in the RAF and Army, I am very grateful to have grown up with these family members and not lost them in the current wars that have been going on. 

I think that this is a brillaint site which has many educational and personal uses.  I hope that many more comments and  appropriate personal memories are added.  Well done to everyone who has built this and are currently adding to it.  I will be sharing this with those whom I think will welcome the opportunity to visit the site.

comment.author: 65928113@N07
comment._content:
Both my grandfathers were in the First World War - one (who was in for the whole war and came through relatively unscathed) was in the Inniskilling Dragoons, and the other (a previously retired regular soldier) served from 1916 onwards with the Royal Engineers.  Three of my grandparents lost brothers in the war.
These pictures are a fitting tribute to the men who suffered and died in that war.  Thank you for making these photographs available.

comment.author: 69729315@N07
comment._content: My great grand father was 11 years old when he joined. Very tall for his age bless him :). I never got the joy of meeting him, he died a fair few years before I was born. I have heard nothing but stories of courage and sadness from family members about ww1. This gallery is indeed a very fitting way to honour the young boys and men that fought, suffered or died in that war. Thank you for sharing the photos.

comment.author: 69729315@N07
comment._content: @ termite1944 You are absolutely spot on... I wonder what they would say!

comment.author: 32241852@N00
comment._content: @ zajm and termite1944 They'd probably say that it was due to racist, right-wing attitudes that we got into that mess, and that this isn't the time or the place to air similar views!

comment.author: 32300107@N06
comment._content: We value all genuine and relevant comments on these portraits -- your feedback is what we want. However, this is no place for political opinions. Please keep the discussion relevant to the individuals in these portraits.

comment.author: 32300107@N06
comment._content: Hi W du Plooy We have a group called 'Your Faces of the First World War' where you can upload your own images and info of those who served in the First World War. You can find it at: www.flickr.com/groups/your_faces_ww1 Many thanks.

comment.author: 45500782@N06
comment._content:
IWM Collections.

Why have you not replied to my question of 3 weeks ago. ?

Do you not care about the fighters of ww2 ? do/did they not exist. ?

comment.author: 32300107@N06
comment._content:
Hi Mrs J C Deppll
This collection contains images of those who served in the First World War, which we have made public in the lead up to the 2014 centenary of the outbreak of the war.
The IWM covers conflicts, especially those involving Britain and the Commonwealth, from the First World War to the present day - including the Second World War. You will find information and items related to Second World War servicemen and women in our Collections and on display at our branches.
Thank you

comment.author: 64617780@N02
comment._content: Mrs J C Deppell You miss the point of this gallery entirely - if you bothered to read any of the introductary information you will have seen it is featuring images of people who served in WW1 as we move towards the centenary of its beginning in 1914. I am sure the IWM would be interested to receive photos of your late father from his RN service in WW2 and perhaps they would be featured in a future gallery commemorating the centenary of WW2. In the meantime just calm down and allow the WW1 participants their place.
